pyexplainer package¶

Submodules¶

pyexplainer.pyexplainer_explainer module¶

class pyexplainer.pyexplainer_explainer.Explainer(bullet_data, risk_data, random_state=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

__init__ method of Explainer class.

Parameters

  • param1 (list of dict) – A list of dictionary that contains the specification of the bullet chart to be created.

  • param2 (list of dict) – A list of dictionary that contains the information about risk scores.

  • param3 (np.random.RandomState, default is None) – A RandomState instance.

generate_html()[source]¶

Generate html and return it as a String.

Returns

html String

Return type

str

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]

show_visualisation()[source]¶

Display the html string in a cell of Jupyter Notebook.

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]
pyexplainer.pyexplainer_explainer.data_validation(data)[source]¶

Validate the if the given data format is a list of dictionary.

Parameters

param1 (Any) – Data to be validated.

Returns

True: The data is a list of dictionary.

False: The data is not a list of dictionary.

Return type

bool

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]
pyexplainer.pyexplainer_explainer.id_generator(size=15, random_state=None)[source]¶

Generate unique ids for div tag which will contain the visualisation stuff from d3.

Parameters

  • param1 (int) – An integer that specifies the length of the returned id, default = 15.

  • param2 (np.random.RandomState, default is None.) – A RandomState instance.

Returns

A random identifier.

Return type

str

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]
